title: 【資産が増える方程式】インフレ時代の投資術／日本人が稼げない理由／収入・資産レベル別の資産形成戦略／お金持ちに共通する特徴とリスク／仕事選びの3要素／市場のブームに乗る条件／己の条件で生きる真の「富」

transcript.text: Did anything inspire you to uh write
your uh new book?
>> So the new book I I wrote it because I
feel like just keep buying is a great
philosophy for most people kind of want
a different perspective or want to look
at things differently and understand
wealth building more holistically and
like a bigger picture. That's what the
wealth ladder is for.
>> The question is like does money buy
happiness? And let's we looked at I
looked at the the studies on this. If
you're already happy more money will
bring more happiness, right? But if
you're not poor and you're not happy,
more money is not going to do a thing
then.
>> What does wealth actually mean?
>> There's a lot of people that can live
life on their own terms. That doesn't
mean you have to be financially free.
Like you can say, "Hey, my terms are I'm
going to have this job. I'm going to go
to work. I'm going to do this stuff, but
on the weekends, I get to go and do this
other thing that I really like and it
doesn't pay me anything, but I just
really enjoy it." And for me, that is
wealth. Having the ability to go and do
stuff you care about is wealth.
Just to Keep buying.
Just keep in
Tommych.
Thank you so much for joining us today.
Um, in Japan, just keep buying has
actually been bred uh even more widely
than in the US and I heard that there
are more than 200,000 copies sold in
Japan and I really think that many
readers in Japan here follow the ideas
of your book very seriously. So today
I'd love to talk about your new book,
The Wealth Ladder, not just as a

perspective. So I want to go beyond
investing and um to talk about work,
spending, and also happiness as well. So
you visited in Japan um in 2024 on a

we're online um I'd love to keep that
experience in mind as we talk especially
in terms of how Japanese readers uh
might approach this book. So to start
and before I dig into the details of
your latest book, can I ask you how you
feel about just keep buying being so
widely read in Japan? I love it and I'm
obviously very grateful. I did not know
that this would happen that it would
take off in such a way and the Japanese
readers would would love it so much and
it's been a pleasant surprise and um
it's even better because obviously after
my wife and I visited uh she really
loved the country and she can't wait to
go back and she's always she's pregnant
now so we're not really traveling much
but she is telling me all the time we
have to go back I'd go back again before
I'd even go to a bunch of new countries.
I'm like okay. So we do have a plan to
go back at some point and we're very
excited. uh to go back at some point.
So, it's been it's been a lot of fun.
>> Oh, great. Great. Did anything inspire
you to uh write your uh new book?
>> So, the new book I I wrote it because I
feel like just keep buying is a great
philosophy for most people and for like
people in, you know, most stages of
their financial lives,
>> but I realize that certain people who
are just starting out, it's not the
right philosophy yet. And then for
people who want like really extreme
wealth, like you know, absolute what I
say in the US is like over$10 million
US, which is a lot of money. Anyone
that's trying to get to that level of
wealth, they need to go beyond just keep
buying. And so it it it applies to, you
know, a lot of different people and it's
a good framework you can keep coming
back to, which is why I like it. So like
just keep buying is one of the
strategies on the ladder. And so I
basically said, hey, let's zoom out and
look at other possible strategies. So
that was the idea behind it. I wanted to
come up with a new framework that people
could come back to. I still think just
keep buying is the perfect like starter
book or helps most people. But for those
people who kind of want a different
perspective or want to look at things
differently and understand wealth
building more holistically and like a
bigger picture, that's what the wealth
ladder is for.
>> Oh, I see. So, um let's uh deep dive
into the details of the wealth ladder.
So, what problem actually is the wealth
ladder trying to solve? And you describe
each level using the price of a decision
and the 0.0.1%
rule. Uh what was your intention behind
explaining the ladder in this way?
>> I think the idea with the ladder was I
wanted to use it as a framework and then
help it um have it help you solve your
income spending and investment choices,
right? Help you with those choices,
right? And so the idea here was,
>> you know, the the analogy I used in in
the introduction was a uh a fitness
instructor would give different advice
to someone who's morbidly obese versus a
well-trained athlete. Like the the the
diet and exercise advice, a lot of the
principles will be the same, but the
specific strategy you follow is going to
change based on where you are. And I
think you can take that analogy and you
can apply it directly to how you use
your money, your wealth building, all
that type of stuff. And so that's kind
of where I came from when I was writing
this. And in terms of like the spending
piece, which you're talking about, the
01% rule, I think the reason why I have
all these rules, I had, you know, rules
for just keep buying. I have rules in
the wealth factors because, you know,
these rules work very well. And and and
you don't have to follow all of them.
I'm just throwing them as options. And
you're like, "Oh, I like that one. Use
it. If you don't like it, don't use it."
Right? So I want to give people options
and different ways of viewing their
money so that they can make better
choices. That's ultimately what all this
is all about. And that's what I was
trying to do with the wealth ladder.
>> I see. So in that sense, like level five
and level six may feel distant for most
people, but you say that they're still
important for those at lower levels. So
does that also mean that you're giving
the options, right?
>> Exactly. I think for level five and six,
obviously most people will never get to
that wealth and they don't need to to
live a good life whatsoever. But I still
think it's useful to think about some of
the mistakes that people in level five
and six make because those same mistakes
overlooking your family, working so much
that you don't have a social life or you
don't do anything else, right? So it's
like there are people that make mistakes
in level fives and level six that apply
to people across the wealth ladder. And
I wanted to focus on those things and
those people tend to do it because they
focus too much on money. And so I was
like, "Hey, what are some of these types
of issues and how do they apply to
everybody?" And so that's kind of what I
tried to do in those chapters, even
though like yes, I will probably never
get to level five or level six. Most
people won't and that's fine, but it's
like what are the the lessons that
anyone can use if you're reading this
book?
>> I see. So how about, you know,
regardless of the level, do you think
that the successful people share certain
mental models or patterns of decision-m?
I haven't studied like a bunch of
successful people and tried to come up
with, you know, some sort of mental
model or decision-m. I do think the one,
if I had to pick one thing, it's
consistency. It's just focusing on
consistency over a very long period of

is like it's very hard to find people
who focused on something for a long time

Because you would never know about them.
They don't write headlines about, hey,

you don't see those headlines, right?
So, because of that, it's kind of hard

that does seem to, you know, be somewhat

successful people is some form of

just keep buying did so well as a book.
It's because it is about instilling that
consistency like literally just keep
buying over time and you can see a lot

And also early in the book uh you

So uh could you briefly walk us through
this framework?
>> Yeah. So there's this idea that you know
how do you choose a job? How do you
choose a career? What you're going to do
with your life?
>> And I said these three things you can
talk about your strengths, what you're
good at,
>> your interests, kind of what you what
you like are passionate about, what you
want to pursue. And then lastly, what

Unless you have money or assets or a

paid initially. They'll save up some

can work on their strengths and then,
you know, the the compliments and the
praise they get from doing something

that's the framework I use in terms of
my writing. I used to hate writing. It's
very funny if someone wrote two books
and I actually wrote them, right? This
was prei I wrote the first one pre AI,
so I didn't have a computer write it,

you know, talk about these types of
things. And so think about that as like
the greater framework like of those
three things, what can you focus on? And
then build on those strengths and and
see where it takes you.
>> Well, yeah, that's that's very

point?

It's nothing like that, but I wasn't

Once again, the the ladder is not meant

so where does that shift start to happen

that's you it's going to be within yen

at that point by that point, your

>> Okay. So, it's not just a matter of age,

>> Right. Right. So um here I'd like to

within inflation continuing in Japan and

uh many people feel a strong sense of

the fear of being left behind if they

>> I can understand the the fear here

the last few decades the the best one of
the best things you could have done was
just hold cash cuz that cash had very
little inflation to even deflation where
so it it held its value for so long. So
in that environment, you never need to
invest, right? Why why would you? You
can just put in a, you know, you
literally leave it under your mattress
as they say, and that is just going to,
you know, that's going to keep its value
and you don't have to worry about it. In
an inflationary environment, it's not
true. When inflation's high, that value
of those dollars or those yen are going
down over time. And so you're kind of
forced to participate to kind of keep
that purchasing power around. And so I
think what's happened and I I could be
wrong on this, but I'm feeling pretty

paradigm shift from CO and everything
that's going on that now like inflation
is here to stay. I'm not saying it's
going to stay this high forever, but it
seems like inflation is going to stay
around, which means the old model is not
going to work anymore. And so you have
to think about investing. You have to
think about getting allocated somewhat.
What I would say is if you're worried
about it, you don't need to put all your
money into investments, put it all into
the Nissa right now. That's not the
goal. start just getting used to putting
some money in there. Just get into a

small. I think the habit is going to be
more important than the amount
necessarily because you'll start putting
some yen in there periodically and
you'll start to see it grow and then if

further. If it doesn't, it'll go down a

about that. It's more about the
long-term accumulation. You need to you

don't just want to put it all in one

and you're going to start to see that
pay off over a long period of time. So
for the anxiety, I I can't I don't know
what it's like to grow up and live in
that environment, but I can tell you
from someone who lives in the
environment that's very similar to like
the current Japanese environment with
normal inflation.
>> It's very regular to invest. It is not a
It seems scary because you guys haven't

>> It it's just the this this is how the

You have to realize that. I mean, I love

which like the rank plots. It shows hey

so these kind of asset quilts as they're
called
>> and those plots are very useful or those
charts are very useful because you can
see the rankings change and an asset
class that did very well in one period
may do very poorly in the next. And so
for example I remember in 2009 2010
everyone said US stocks are dead. Like
they're done like international is
better. You shouldn't even allocate to
the US. US is a mess. And guess what?
The US has been one of the best, if not

like just because something has a bad

look, now the market's up and now we're

things change. I mean, the world

>> So, how about the market booms like the
AI stocks, the cryptos, uh, gold, and
that happens everywhere? But, and I
think that the riding the wave can work
sometimes, but under what condition does
